text: We were obsessed with reducing friction, this was our constant battle. And so we hired a couple of college interns and we brought them in and we were like, people are going to push this magical one button in the Anchor app and they're going to say, I want to distribute my podcast, and your job is going to be to do all that same manual stuff manually, but to them it's going to feel magical and it happened automatically.
speaker: Maya Prohovnik
context: Maya is sharing an early Anchor story about how they solved podcast distribution challenges. At the time, distributing podcasts to platforms like Apple Podcasts was extremely technical and difficult for creators - requiring Apple IDs, understanding RSS feeds, and dealing with technical hurdles. Maya explains how they created what appeared to be an automated solution by having college interns manually handle all the technical distribution work behind the scenes, making it feel seamless for users.
vocabulary_highlights: feel magical and it happened automatically
text_ko: 우리는 마찰(friction)을 줄이는 데 집착했어요. 그게 늘 우리의 싸움이었죠. 그래서 대학생 인턴 몇 명을 고용해 데려왔어요. 그리고 '사람들이 앵커 앱(Anchor app)의 마법 같은 버튼 하나를 누르고 “내 팟캐스트를 배포하고 싶어요”라고 하면, 너희는 그 모든 수작업을 대신 해주면 된다. 사용자들에겐 이게 자동으로 된 것처럼, 마법처럼 느껴질 거다'라고 말했어요.
text_zh: 我们当时就是死磅着要减少用户的操作难度，这是我们一直在攻克的难题。所以我们就招了几个大学实习生过来，跟他们说，用户在Anchor应用里只要按一个神奇的按钮，说"我要分发我的播客"，然后你们的工作就是在后台手动把那些繁琐的活儿都给干了，但对用户来说感觉就像变魔术一样，一切都是自动完成的。
text_es: Estábamos obsesionados con eliminar fricciones, esa era nuestra batalla constante. Entonces contratamos a un par de becarios universitarios y cuando llegaron les dijimos: la gente va a tocar este botón mágico en la app de Anchor y va a decir "quiero distribuir mi podcast", y su trabajo va a ser hacer toda esa misma tarea manual a mano, pero para ellos va a sentirse mágico, como si hubiera pasado automáticamente.

text: I think data is amazing and I'm like, we have such an incredible insights team at Spotify, both my insights team and then the broader one. I think we are so lucky and we have so much knowledge about our users and different cohorts and what people need and what they're missing, and so I think that's extremely valuable. I think where people get into trouble is when they think that they can rely solely on the data.
speaker: Maya Prohovnik
context: Lenny asks Maya about finding the balance between being data-driven versus gut-driven in product decisions, noting this is something many product leaders struggle with. Maya is explaining her philosophy on using data effectively while warning against over-reliance on data alone. She advocates for using data as one input among many in the creative product development process rather than as the sole decision-making framework.
text_ko: 저는 데이터가 정말 놀랍다고 생각해요. 그리고 우리 스포티파이에 인사이트 팀(insights team)이 정말 대단하다고 느껴요 — 제 인사이트 팀도 있고, 더 큰 조직 차원의 팀도 있고요. 우리가 참 운이 좋다고 생각해요. 사용자들에 대해, 다양한 코호트(cohorts)별로 사람들이 무엇을 필요로 하고 무엇이 부족한지에 대해 정말 많은 지식을 가지고 있고, 그게 엄청난 가치라고 봐요. 사람들이 곤란해지는 건 데이터를 전적으로, 오로지 데이터에만 의존할 수 있다고 생각할 때예요.
text_zh: 我觉得数据真的太厉害了，我们Spotify的洞察团队简直不要太强，不管是我自己的团队还是整个大团队。我们真的太幸运了，对用户了解得特别透彻，各种用户群体(cohorts)都摸得很清楚，知道大家需要什么、缺什么，这真的是超级宝贵的资源。但我觉得问题就出在，有些人以为光靠数据就能搞定一切，这就容易出事了。
text_es: Creo que los datos son increíbles y es que tenemos un equipo de insights súper bueno en Spotify, tanto mi equipo como el más amplio. Creo que tenemos muchísima suerte y sabemos un montón sobre nuestros usuarios y los diferentes segmentos, qué necesita la gente y qué les falta, entonces eso me parece súper valioso. Pero creo que donde la gente se mete en problemas es cuando piensan que se pueden basar únicamente en los datos.

text: I think something that I've had to learn is that being gut driven isn't the same as just saying to people, I told you or I believe this, so you have to do it. There really is an art I think to balancing that. And I think that what I try to do is always still as objectively as possible explain why my gut is feeling that way.
speaker: Maya Prohovnik
context: Maya continues discussing how to balance gut instinct with data in product decisions, specifically addressing the challenge of leading in a large organization. She's explaining how being gut-driven requires more sophistication when you need to influence many stakeholders who aren't on your immediate team. Maya emphasizes that gut instinct must be communicated with objective reasoning and supporting evidence to be effective in larger organizational contexts.
text_ko: 제가 배워야 했던 것 중 하나는, 직감(gut-driven)에 따라 움직인다는 게 단순히 '내가 옳았잖아요'라며 사람들에게 '그러니까 그대로 해요'라고 강요하는 것과는 다르다는 점이에요. 그 균형을 잡는 건 정말 묘한 감각이 필요해요. 그래서 저는 항상 가능한 한 객관적으로 제 직감이 왜 그런지 설명하려고 해요.
text_zh: 我觉得我学到的一点就是，凭直觉做决策不等于直接跟人说"我早就告诉你了"或者"我就是这么想的，你必须照做"。在这方面真的需要平衡的艺术。我现在尽量做的就是，还是要尽可能客观地解释为什么我的直觉是这样的。
text_es: Creo que algo que he tenido que aprender es que dejarse llevar por la intuición no es lo mismo que simplemente decirle a la gente "yo te dije" o "yo creo esto, así que tienes que hacerlo". Realmente hay todo un arte en encontrar ese equilibrio. Y lo que trato de hacer es siempre explicar de la forma más objetiva posible por qué mi intuición me dice eso.

text: I think you really have to be able to tell the signal through the noise, and even if you've got lots of vocal users asking for something, we used to have this rule, the 80/20 rule, where it's like you can't just build for that 20, I don't think we made this up by the way. I think this is a common thing, but we'd always refer to it and say, we want to be building for the 80%, and even though the 20% are going to be more vocal, that's just going to get you deeper into that hole of that problem of you're not really building for everyone.
speaker: Maya Prohovnik
context: Lenny asks Maya about the difficult decision to change Anchor from version 1.0 to 2.0 despite having users who loved the existing product. Maya is explaining the challenge of making strategic product decisions when you have satisfied but vocal users who represent a minority. She's describing how they learned to distinguish between feedback from power users versus the broader market they wanted to serve, emphasizing the importance of building for mainstream adoption rather than just the most engaged current users.
vocabulary_highlights: tell the signal through the noise
text_ko: 정말로 노이즈 속에서 신호(signal through the noise)를 가려낼 줄 알아야 해요. 목소리 큰 사용자들이 많이 뭔가를 요청하더라도요. 예전부터 우리는 80/20 규칙(80/20 rule)을 갖고 있었는데, 그 규칙은 '그 20%만을 위해 만들 수 없다'는 뜻이에요. 참고로 이건 우리가 새로 만든 얘기가 아니라 다들 갖고 있는 생각인 것 같아요. 그래서 항상 그걸 기준으로 삼아서 '우리는 80%를 위해 만들어야 한다'고 말했어요. 20%가 더 시끄럽다고 거기에만 신경 쓰다 보면 오히려 문제의 구멍에 더 깊이 빠져서 결국 모두를 위한 제품을 만들지 못하게 돼요.
text_zh: 我觉得你得能够从噪音中找到真正的信号，就算有很多用户在那儿大声要求什么功能，我们以前有个规矩，就是二八定律(80/20 rule)，你不能只为那20%的人做产品。顺便说一句，这不是我们发明的，这应该是个常识吧。但我们总是会提到这个，说我们要为80%的用户做产品，虽然那20%的用户声音更大，但如果你只听他们的，只会让你越陷越深，到头来你做出来的产品根本不是给所有人用的。
text_es: Creo que realmente tienes que saber separar lo importante del ruido, y aunque tengas muchos usuarios que se quejan pidiendo algo, nosotros teníamos esta regla, la regla del 80/20, donde no puedes construir solo para ese 20%, y por cierto, no creo que se nos haya ocurrido a nosotros. Creo que es algo común, pero siempre la mencionábamos y decíamos, queremos construir para el 80%, y aunque ese 20% va a hacer más ruido, eso solo te va a meter más profundo en ese hoyo de ese problema de que en realidad no estás construyendo para todos.

text: I think you really have to stick to it and it's really hard, but you have to keep pivoting to get to where you want to be. Kill your darlings. I love that phrase, I use it all the time.
speaker: Maya Prohovnik
context: Maya and Lenny are discussing the challenge of having a product that's working but not achieving massive scale. Maya is explaining the importance of staying committed to your larger mission and vision, even when it means making difficult decisions to change things that are currently working. She references the common creative writing advice about 'killing your darlings' - being willing to cut things you love if they don't serve the bigger picture.
text_ko: 정말 끝까지 밀고 나가야 해요. 진짜 힘들지만 원하는 곳에 가려면 계속 피벗(pivoting)해 가며 방향을 조정해야 해요. 애정 있는 아이디어도 과감히 버려야 해요 (Kill your darlings). 그 표현 정말 좋아해요, 저도 항상 써요.
text_zh: 我觉得你真的得坚持下去，虽然特别难，但你必须不断调整方向(pivot)才能到达你想要的地方。要舍得放弃心爱的项目，我特别喜欢这个说法，经常用。
text_es: Creo que realmente tienes que ser constante y es súper difícil, pero hay que seguir adaptándose para llegar donde quieres estar. Mata a tus niños bonitos (kill your darlings). Me encanta esa frase, la uso todo el tiempo.

text: I still don't know how many people know this. I think people think that we had some secret backdoor deal with Apple for distribution, but we just had college students making Apple podcast accounts and then submitting hundreds of thousands of podcasts through these accounts, and I think that was a really big part of why we got so much hosting market share so quickly because it was such an insane benefit over the other platforms which otherwise had been commoditized at that point.
speaker: Maya Prohovnik
context: Maya is elaborating on the earlier story about Anchor's unscalable solution for podcast distribution. She explains how they gained competitive advantage by making distribution appear automated when it was actually manual work done by interns. This created a remarkable user experience that drove word-of-mouth growth and helped them capture significant market share in podcast hosting, as competitors were offering similar technical features but without the ease-of-use advantage.
text_ko: 이 사실을 얼마나 많은 사람이 알고 있는지는 아직 잘 모르겠어요. 사람들은 우리가 유통을 위해 Apple과 은밀한 백도어 거래(backdoor deal)를 한 것처럼 생각하는 것 같은데, 실제로는 대학생들이 Apple 팟캐스트 계정(Apple podcast accounts)을 만들어 그 계정들로 수십만 개의 팟캐스트를 제출했을 뿐이에요. 그게 당시 다른 플랫폼들이 이미 상품화(commoditized)돼 있던 상황에서 비교할 수 없을 만큼 큰 이점이었기 때문에 우리가 그렇게 빨리 호스팅 시장 점유율(hosting market share)을 많이 확보할 수 있었던 큰 이유 중 하나였다고 생각해요.
text_zh: 我觉得知道这件事的人还不多。大家可能以为我们跟苹果有什么私下的分发协议，其实根本不是这样的。我们就是找了一堆大学生去注册苹果播客账号，然后通过这些账号提交了几十万个播客，我觉得这就是我们能这么快拿到这么大市场份额的关键原因，因为这个优势太明显了，而其他平台那时候已经没什么差异化了，都差不多。
text_es: Todavía no sé cuánta gente sabe esto. Creo que la gente piensa que teníamos algún acuerdo por debajo de la mesa con Apple para la distribución, pero simplemente teníamos estudiantes universitarios creando cuentas de podcast de Apple y luego subiendo cientos de miles de podcasts a través de esas cuentas, y creo que eso fue una parte súper importante de por qué conseguimos tanto market share de hosting tan rápido porque era una ventaja brutal comparado con las otras plataformas que ya se habían commoditizado para ese momento.
